candela: In the International System of Units, the base unit of luminous intensity; the luminous intensity, in a given direction, of a source that emits monochromatic radiation of frequency 540 × 1012 hertz and that has a radiant intensity in that direction of 1/683 watt per steradian. Symbol: cd
candidacy: The state of being a candidate.
candidate: A person who is running in an election.
candidature: The condition of becoming a candidate.
candiru: A small parasitic fish, Vandellia cirrhosa, native to the Amazon river.
candle: A light source consisting of a wick embedded in a solid, flammable substance such as wax, tallow, or paraffin.
candleberry: Any of the plants in the genus Myrica, containing about 35-50 species of small trees and shrubs in the family Myricaceae, order Fagales, with a wide distribution, including Africa, Asia, Europe, North America and South America.
candlefish: An oily edible fish, Thaleichthys pacificus, from the northern Pacific, that was once dried and used as a candle or torch by the Chinook Indians.
candleholder: A device for holding one or more lit candles
candlelight: The light emitted by a candle.
candlelit: Lit by a candle or candles.
candlenut: A flowering tree (Aleurites moluccana and Aleurites rockinghamensis) of the family Euphorbiaceae, also known as candleberry, Indian walnut, kemiri, varnish tree or kukui nut tree.
candlestick: A holder with a socket or spike for a candle.
candlewick: The thread used to make the wicks of candles
candy: Edible, sweet-tasting confectionery containing sugar, or sometimes artificial sweeteners, and often flavored with fruit, chocolate, nuts, herbs and spices, or artificial flavors.
A unit of mass used in southern India, equal to twenty maunds, roughly equal to 500 pounds avoirdupois but varying locally.
candytuft: An annual plant of the genus Iberis.
cane: A plant with simple stems, like bamboo or sugar cane, or the stem thereof
canebrake: A dense thicket of sugarcane, bamboo or similar plants.
canid: Any member of the family Canidae, including dogs, wolves, foxes, coyotes and jackals.
canine: Any member of Caninae, the only living subfamily of Canidae.
canister: A cylindrical or rectangular container usually of lightweight metal, plastic, or laminated pasteboard used for holding a dry product (as tea, crackers, flour, matches).
canker: A plant disease marked by gradual decay.
To affect as a canker; to eat away; to corrode; to consume.
cankered: Infected with a canker or having a cankerous part
To affect as a canker; to eat away; to corrode; to consume.
cankerworm: Either of two caterpillars, the larvae of geometrid moths, that are destructive to fruit, buds and leaves.
Canna: Any member of the genus Canna of tropical plants with large leaves and often showy flowers.
A measure of length in Italy, varying from six to seven feet.
canna: Any member of the genus Canna of tropical plants with large leaves and often showy flowers.
A measure of length in Italy, varying from six to seven feet.
cannabinol: A psychoactive cannabinoid found in the hemp plant Cannabis sativa; an oxidation product of tetrahydrocannabinol (THC).
Cannabis: A tall annual dioecious plant (Cannabis, especially Cannabis sativa), native to central Asia and having alternate, palmately divided leaves and tough bast fibers.
cannelure: A ringlike groove, such as that around the cylinder of an elongated bullet for small arms to contain a lubricant, or around the rotating band of a gun projectile to lessen the resistance offered to the rifling.
cannery: A factory that produces canned goods.
cannibal: An organism which eats others of its own species or kind, especially a human who eats human flesh.
cannibalism: The act of eating another of one's own species.
cannibalize: To eat (parts of) another of one's own species.
cannon: A complete assembly, consisting of an artillery tube and a breech mechanism, firing mechanism or base cap, which is a component of a gun, howitzer or mortar. It may include muzzle appendages.
cannonade: Firing artillery in a large amount for a length of time .
cannoneer: A person who tends and operates a piece of artillery, especially a cannon.
cannula: A tube inserted in the body to drain or inject fluid.
cannulate: To use a cannula; to insert a tube, particularly into a vein
cannulated: To use a cannula; to insert a tube, particularly into a vein
canny: (especially of sound) Sounding as if it is coming through a tin can.
canoe: A small long and narrow boat, propelled by one or more people (depending on the size of canoe), using single-bladed paddles. The paddlers face in the direction of travel, in either a seated position, or kneeling on the bottom of the boat. Canoes are open on top, and pointed at both ends.
canoeing: To ride or paddle a canoe.
canon: A generally accepted principle; a rule.
A clergy member serving a cathedral or collegiate church.
A Near Eastern and Caucasian musical instrument related to the zither, dulcimer, or harp having either 26 strings and a single bridge, or twice that number and two bridges.
canoness: A woman who holds a canonry in a conventual chapter.
canonical: The formal robes of a priest.
canonicals: The formal robes of a priest.
canonicity: The degree to which something is canonical.
canonist: An expert in canon law; canon lawyer
canonization: The final process or decree (following beatification) by which the name of a deceased person is placed in the catalogue (canon) of saints and commended to perpetual veneration and invocation.
canonize: To declare (a deceased person) as a saint, and enter them into the canon of saints.
canonry: The office of a canon; a benefice or prebend in a cathedral or collegiate church.
canopy: A high cover providing shelter, such as a cloth supported above an object, particularly over a bed.
capon: A cockerel which has been gelded and fattened for the table.
caponier: A type of fortification structure which allows firing along the bottom of a dry moat that surrounds the main fortress.
caponize: To castrate (a cockerel) in order to fatten it for table use.
capot: A winning of all the tricks in the game of piquet, counting for forty points.
capote: A long coat or cloak with a hood.
capped: To cover or seal with a cap.
capper: A person who records a television broadcast to their computer.
capping: To cover or seal with a cap.
capriccio: A sudden and unexpected or fantastic motion; a caper (from same etymology, see below); a gambol; a prank, a trick.
caprice: An impulsive, seemingly unmotivated action, change of mind, or notion.
capricious: Impulsive and unpredictable; determined by chance, impulse, or whim
caprine: Any of certain caprids (including sheep) that are regarded as being similar to the goat; any member of the tribe Caprini.
The triglyceride of capric acid; a constituent of butterfat
capriole: A leap that a horse makes with all fours, upwards only, without advancing, but with a kick or jerk of the hind legs when at the height of the leap.
caprylate: Any salt or ester of caprylic acid
capsaicin: A chemical compound found in chilli peppers, which is responsible for their pungent flavor.
Capsicum: Any of several tropical American plants, of the genus Capsicum, principally the species Capsicum annuum and Capsicum frutescens, that are cultivated as edible peppers.
capsicum: Any of several tropical American plants, of the genus Capsicum, principally the species Capsicum annuum and Capsicum frutescens, that are cultivated as edible peppers.
capsid: The outer protein shell of a virus
capstan: A vertical cylindrical machine that revolves on a spindle, used to apply force to ropes, cables, etc. It is typically surmounted by a drumhead with sockets for levers used to turn it.
capstone: Any of the stones making up the top layer of a wall; a coping stone.
captaincy: The rank or status of a captain.
caption: The descriptive heading or title of a document or part therof
captious: That captures; especially, (of an argument, words etc.) designed to capture or entrap in misleading arguments; sophistical.
captivate: To attract and hold interest and attention of; charm.
captivating: To attract and hold interest and attention of; charm.
captive: One who has been captured or is otherwise confined.
captor: One who is holding a captive or captives.
capture: An act of capturing; a seizing by force or stratagem.
Capuchin: A monk in the Order of Friars Minor Capuchin; (generally) a Franciscan.
capuchin: A monk in the Order of Friars Minor Capuchin; (generally) a Franciscan.
capybara: A semi-aquatic South American rodent, Hydrochoerus hydrochaeris, the largest living rodent.
car: A wheeled vehicle that moves independently, with at least three wheels, powered mechanically, steered by a driver and mostly for personal transportation.
The first part of a cons in LISP. The first element of a list
carabao: A domesticated subspecies of water-buffalo, Bubalus bubalis carabanesis.
carabid: Any of the family Carabidae, the ground beetles.
caracal: A type of cat native to Southern Africa, West Asia, and parts of Central and South Asia, Caracal caracal.
caracara: Any of several South American and Central American birds of prey in the family Falconidae.
caracole: A half-turn performed by a horse and rider in dressage.
carafe: A bottle, usually glass and with a flared lip, used for serving water, wine, or other beverages.
Caragana: Any of several shrubs or small trees, of the genus Caragana, that often have golden flowers
caramba: (non-vulgar) Exclamation of surprise or dismay.; golly!
carambola: A tree species native of southern Asia, Averrhoa carambola.
caramel: A smooth, chewy, sticky confection made by heating sugar and other ingredients until the sugars polymerize and become sticky.
carangid: Any fish belonging to the family Carangidae.
carapace: A hard protective covering of bone or chitin, especially one which covers the dorsal portion of an animal.
carat: A unit of weight for precious stones and pearls, equivalent to 200 milligrams.
caravan: A convoy or procession of travelers, their vehicles and cargo, and any pack animals, especially camels crossing a desert.
caravansary: A roadside inn having a central courtyard where caravans can rest.
caravanserai: A roadside inn having a central courtyard where caravans can rest.
caravel: A light, usually lateen-rigged sailing ship used by the Portuguese and Spanish for about 300 years from the 15th century, first for trade and later for voyages of exploration.
caraway: A biennial plant, Carum carvi, native to Europe and Asia, mainly grown for its seed to be used as a culinary spice.
carbamate: Any salt or ester of carbamic acid.
carbazole: A tricyclic aromatic organic compound containing two benzene rings fused to a pyrrole ring.
carbene: Any short-lived, reactive species R2C:, especially the parent compound CH2: (also called methylene).
carbide: Any binary compound of carbon and a more electropositive element
carbine: A rifle with a short barrel.
